Literature Review: The gauge hierarchy problem is a fundamental issue in particle physics, arising from the apparent fine-tuning required to explain the observed mass of the Higgs boson. The Higgs mass, m_H, is sensitive to quantum corrections from high-energy scales, which suggests the presence of new physics at or around the TeV scale to stabilize it. However, experimental results from the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) have not yet discovered any new particles at this energy range, challenging traditional solutions to the hierarchy problem. This literature review explores recent approaches that do not necessitate new particles at the TeV scale, focusing on the relaxation approach, the historical approach, and solutions using conditional probability.
